questions.text: The cecal bud arises from _______
questions.solution:
The cecal bud arises as a diverticulum in the post-arterial segment of the midgut loop.

The cecal bud enlarges and gives rise to the cecum and the appendix. The proximal part of the cecal bud grows rapidly to form the cecum. The distal part remains narrow and forms the appendix. 

The midgut loop consists of a cranial limb and a caudal limb. 

  • The cranial limb forms the jejunum and upper part of the ileum.
  • The caudal limb forms the lower part of the ileum, cecum, appendix, ascending colon, and proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon.

questions.text: Positive feedback action of estrogen for inducing luteinizing hormone surge is associated with which of the following steroid hormone ratio in peripheral circulation?
questions.solution:
Positive feedback action of estrogen for inducing luteinizing hormone (LH) surge is associated with high estrogen: low progesterone.

Phases

Hormone

Type of feedback

Site

FSH and LH secretion

Follicular

Estrogen

Negative

Anterior pituitary

Both suppressed

Midcycle

Estrogen

Positive

Anterior pituitary

Increased LH surge

Luteal

Estrogen

Progesterone

Negative

Negative

Anterior pituitary

Anterior pituitary

Both are decreased

Related Pearl: Hormonal Regulation of Menstrual Cycle

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the effect of substrate concentration on the rate of reaction?

choices.text: As substrate concentration increases, the initial velocity of the reaction increases until it reaches a maximum value (Vmax)
The substrate concentration at which the velocity of the reaction is half maximum is called Km
The Michaelis-Menten equation says that initial reaction velocity (Vi) = Vmax [S]/ Km+[S]
The plot of initial reaction velocity against substrate concentration is linear

questions.solution:
The plot of initial reaction velocity against substrate concentration is hyperbolic.

For a typical enzyme, as the substrate concentration increases, initial velocity (Vi) increases until it reaches a maximum value Vmax. With further increase in the substrate concentration, the enzyme is said to be “saturated” with the substrate and the velocity remains the same. Hence, the shape of the curve that relates to the velocity of the reaction to substrate concentration is hyperbolic.

The Michaelis-Menten equation illustrates mathematically the relationship between Vi and [S] i.e,

Vi = Vmax ×[S]/Km+[S]

The Michaelis constant (Km) is the substrate concentration at which Vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2).

questions.text: Increased incidence of cancer in old age is due to _____.
questions.solution:
Increased incidence of cancer in old age is due to telomerase reactivation.

With every cell division, there is some shortening of telomeres at the ends of chromosomes. Once the telomeres are shortened beyond a certain point, it may cause cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis. This is called replicative senescence.

Telomerase is the enzyme that prevents the shortening of telomeres.

This enzyme is present in some cells, like the germ cells, and absent in most somatic cells.

Reactivation of telomerase is a critical step in the development of about 85% of human cancers, which enables the cells to divide for several times than normal.

questions.text: What is the stain used for identifying cryptococcus?
questions.solution:
Mucicarmine is used to stain cryptococcus.

Mucicarmine stain of lung tissue:

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Uses
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages in Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen- positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal-cell carcinoma)
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin in nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis; Differentiate amyloid from collagen
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle in connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers to distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers in malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids: Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms
Masson’s Fontana Melanin and argentaffin Cells
Gomori Methenamine Silver Fungi
Luxol Fast Blue (LFB) Myelin
Phosphotungstic Acid-hematoxylin Cross striations of skeletal muscle, fibrin
Toluidine blue Mast cells
Warthin–Starry Helicobacter pylori, spirochetes
Van Gieson Collagen fibres
Mucicarmine Mucin, Cryptococcus capsule

questions.text: A female patient presented with nausea, vomiting and dizziness. She has been taking medication for an amebiasis infection. She was at a party with her friends and had some alcoholic drinks before the symptoms started. The doctors suspect an interaction between alcohol and the anti-amoebic drug she was taking. What could the drug be?
questions.solution:
The patient is probably having a disulfiram-like reaction, which can occur when metronidazole interacts with alcohol. 

Disulfiram is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor and is used in disulfiram aversion therapy to reduce alcohol dependence. If alcohol is ingested after taking disulfiram, there is an increase in blood acetaldehyde concentration that causes symptoms such as flushing, burning sensation, vomiting, perspiration, tightness of chest, dizziness, throbbing headache, visual disturbance, etc. Knowledge of this may help the patient to resist drinking.

Disulfiram-like reaction is the same reaction mentioned above that has been noted in patients who take the following drugs with alcohol:

  • Metronidazole
  • Sulfonylureas
  • Cefoperazone
  • Procarbazine
  • Griseofulvin

questions.text: Section 192 of IPC deals with _______

choices.text: Using evidence known to be false

questions.solution:
Section 192 of IPC deals with fabricating false evidence.

Note: Section 177 of the IPC deals with furnishing false information.

Related Pearl: Doctor and The Court

IPC section

BNS Section

Section it deals with

229

  • Any other case: up to 3 yrs of imprisonment and fine

196

233

Using evidence known to be false

197

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with uncontrolled chronic hypertension presented with episodes of coughing out frank blood to the ENT surgeon. On further evaluation, a diagnosis of posterior epistaxis secondary to hypertension was made. What is the location of the artery attributing to this bleed?
questions.solution:
The artery responsible for posterior epistaxis is sphenopalatine artery. It is located in the posterior end of middle turbinate.

Most common artery involved in both anterior and posterior epistaxis is the sphenopalatine artery and not the woodruff's plexus.Woodruff's plexus is a venous plexus located in the posterior end of the inferior turbinate and is also sometimes implicated in epistaxis associated with systemic conditions such as hypertension and coagulopathy. However, it only accounts for about 5-10% of all nose bleeds.

questions.text: 3 months following cataract surgery, a patient comes with complaints of decreased visual acuity. On examination, posterior capsular opacification is seen. What type of laser can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given history mentions decreased visual acuity 3 months post-cataract surgery and the presence of posterior capsular opacification is suggestive of after-cataract. A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment.

Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. The rate of posterior capsule opacification following extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) and phacoemulsification varies with the age of the patient, the surgeon, the surgical technique, the type of intraocular lens used, and the duration after surgery.

Symptoms of after cataract include:

  • Reduction of visual acuity
  • Slowly worsening blurring
  • Glare and occasionally monocular diplopia

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

Treatment:

  • Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy: The laser used in posterior capsulotomy is Nd: YAG laser (1064 nm) whose principle is photodisruption. The plasma produced at the laser target expands and disrupts the tissues creating an opening.
  • Surgical treatment: Posterior capsular opacification is managed by creating an opening on the posterior capsule along the visual axis, a procedure called a posterior capsulotomy.

Related Pearl: Lasers in Ophthalmology

Laser Wavelength (Nanometers) Clinical applications
Nd:YAG 1064
  • Posterior capsulotomy
  • Iridotomy
  • Hyloidotomy
Frequency doubled Nd:YAG 532
  • Retinal photocoagulation
  • Cyclo photocoagulation
Argon green 514
  • Trabeculoplasty
  • Iridoplasty
  • Pupillomydriasis
  • Retinal photo-coagulation
Diode laser 810
  • Retinal photo-coagulation
Krypton red 714
  • Retinal photo-coagulation
Excimer (Argon fluoride) 193
  • Photo-refractive keratectomy (PRK)
  • Photo-therapeutic keratectomy (PTK)
  • LASIK
  • LASEK
Femtosecond laser (neodymium - glass) 1053
  • Femtosecond laser-assisted refractive surgery and lamellar and full-thickness corneal transplants

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: WHO stage IV HIV includes all except______
questions.solution:
Esophageal candidiasis is present in HIV stage IV and not oral thrush.

Oral thrush is in stage III

 HIV clinical stage IV includes:

  • HIV wasting syndrome or Slim disease
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (previously known pneumocystis carinii)
  • Recurrent severe bacterial pneumonia
  • Chronic herpes simplex infection (orolabial, genital, anorectal)
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Extrapulmonary TB
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Cytomegalovirus disease
  • CNS toxoplasmosis
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis
  • Disseminated non tuberculous mycobacteria
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis
  • Chronic isospriasis
  • Disseminated mycosis (histoplasmosis, coccidiomycosis)
  • Recurrent septicemia (including nontyphoidal salmonella)
  • Lymphoma (cerebral or B cell non-Hodgkin)
  • Invasive cervical carcinoma
  • Atypical disseminated leishmaniasis
  • HIV associated nephropathy or HIV associated cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A large number of tests were done in series. Which of the following will be true?

choices.text: Sensitivity will decrease, specificity will increase
Sensitivity will increase, specificity will decrease

questions.solution:
When a large number of tests are done in series, net sensitivity is decreased and net specificity is increased.

Screening tests are done in series when the result of the first test determines whether to run the second test or not. e.g., HIV screening is done using consecutive ELISA.

Screening tests are done in parallel when the second test is independently performed regardless of what the first test result is. Both the tests are done at the same time. E.g., In LFT, multiple tests are done together like SGOT, SGPT, total bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, etc.

Following are the trends that are observed while evaluating screening tests:

  Tests in Series Tests in parallel
Combined sensitivity  Decreases Increases
Combined specificity Increases Decreases
Combined PPV Increases Decreases
Combined NPV Decreases  Increases

questions.text: An Accredited Social Health Worker will visit all the babies born at home upto which day of their life:
questions.solution:
Under the Home Based Newborn Care, ASHAs will make visits to all newborns up to 42 days of their life to record weight, ensure vaccination, and registration.

The schedule of her visit is day 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42. On completion of all these visits, ASHA receives an incentive of Rs.250.

She will make:

  • 7 visits to those born at home.
  • 6 visits to those born in a facility through a vaginal delivery (no visit on day 1).
  • 5 visits to those born in a facility through a LSCS (no visit on day 1 and day 3).

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient presents with symptoms of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and gastrinoma with cutaneous angiofibromas. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of MEN 1 syndrome.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes are characterized by tumors of two or more endocrine glands. There are four major types of MEN (MEN 1–4), and they either show an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance or occur sporadically. 

MEN 1, also known as Wermer’s syndrome, is characterized by the triad of parathyroid, pancreatic islet cell, and anterior pituitary tumors. Adrenal cortical tumors, carcinoid tumors, facial angiofibromas, collagenomas, thyroid tumors, and lipomas may also occur. MEN 1-associated tumors are usually multiple, larger, and more aggressive, resulting in resistance to treatment and poor patient outcomes.

  1. Parathyroid tumors- primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common feature of MEN 1. Hypercalcemia with or without symptoms (polyuria, polydipsia, constipation, dyspepsia), nephrolithiasis, and osteitis fibrosa cystica may also occur. All four parathyroid glands are usually affected with multiple adenomas or hyperplasia. 
  2. Pancreatic islet cell tumors- these are neuroendocrine tumors, including:
    • Gastrinoma (gastrin-secreting tumors)- associated with increased gastric acid secretion and multiple peptic ulcers (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). Patients may present with diarrhea and steatorrhea. Gastrinomas are the major cause of mortality and morbidity. 
    • Insulinoma (insulin-secreting tumors)- patients present with hypoglycemic symptoms (weakness, headaches, sweating, seizures, weight gain) that develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake. Along with increased plasma insulin levels and hypoglycemia, increased C peptide and proinsulin levels help in diagnosing the condition.
    • Glucagonoma (glucagon-secreting tumors)- may be associated with necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss, anemia, and stomatitis. 
    • VIPomas (Vasoactive intestinal peptide [VIP]-secreting tumors): The VIPoma syndrome, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. These are mostly located in the tail of the pancreas.
    • PPomas (Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting tumors) and nonfunctioning pancreatic tumors- are associated with a worse prognosis as they often go undiagnosed due to the absence of both clinical features and biochemical abnormalities.
  3. Pituitary tumors- manifestations depend on the hormone secreted (symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, or Cushing’s disease) and tumor size (visual disturbances or hypopituitarism due to compression of the optic chiasm or normal pituitary tissue). 

Surgical excision of the nonmetastatic tumor after localization is the curative treatment. Appropriate medical therapy can be used for some tumors when surgery is contraindicated or unsuccessful (calcimemetics for parathyroid tumors, parietal cell H+-K+-ATPase inhibitors for gastrinomas). In case of metastasis, chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, radiation therapy, and artery embolization may be successful.

MEN 1 occurs due to a mutation in the MEN1 gene located on chromosome 11q13. Mutational genetic analysis is necessary to confirm the clinical diagnosis and identify family members who harbor the mutation and require screening for tumor detection and early treatment.

Other options:

Options B and C: MEN 2, also called Sipple’s syndrome, is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid tumors. This occurs due to mutations of the rearranged during transfection (RET) protooncogene. There are three clinical variants -

  1. MEN 2A (most common): MTC is associated with pheochromocytomas in 50% of patients and parathyroid tumors in 20% of patients. MEN 2A may also be associated with Hirschsprung’s disease and cutaneous lichen amyloidosis.
  2. MEN 2B (MEN 3): MTC is associated with pheochromocytoma, along with Marfanoid habitus; mucosal neuromas of the lips, tongue, and eyelids; medullated corneal fibers; and intestinal autonomic ganglion dysfunction leading to multiple diverticulae and megacolon. Parathyroid tumors are usually absent.
  3. MTC only (FMTC): MTC is the only manifestation.

Option D: MEN 4 is characterized by a combination of MEN 1–associated tumors and CDKN1B mutation-related tumors (gonadal, adrenal, renal, and thyroid tumors).

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except :
questions.solution:
Melanoma is not an AIDS-defining malignancy.

AIDS-defining malignancies are those cancers that a human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infected person is at a high risk of developing. When a HIV-infected person develops one of the AIDS-defining malignancies it suggests that he has AIDS.

AIDS-defining malignancies include the following: 

  • Kaposi sarcoma - It is a multicentric neoplasm of vascular origin and has strong association with HHV - 8.
  • Non-Hodgkins lymphoma and
  • Invasive cervical cancer. 

Given below is the image of kaposi sarcoma:

Note : The FDA has approved pomalidomide, a thalidomide analogue to be included in treating adult patients with AIDS-related Kaposi's sarcoma after failure of highly active antiretroviral therapy and Kaposi's sarcoma in adult patients who are HIV-negative.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman was found to have a restrictive disease with reduced lung volumes on a pulmonary function test. A high-resolution CT of the thorax was done and is shown below.  Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above HRCT shows a honeycomb appearance of lung parenchyma due to interstitial fibrosis in a restrictive lung disorder that is suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD). Inspiratory coarse crackles are not a feature of interstitial lung disease.

Auscultating a patient with ILD will reveal bilateral basal end-inspiratory fine crackles also called velcro crackles or rales.

Patients with interstitial lung disease usually present with a non-productive cough and breathlessness on exertion. Clubbing may be seen on examination, especially in advanced cases.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, with oliguria for 3 days. On Investigations, urine osmolality was 800 mOsm/kg, urinary sodium 10meq/l, and BUN: Creatinine ratio was 20:1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given picture is highly suggestive of Prerenal AKI as urine osmolality is >500 mOsm/kg, urinary sodium<20 meq/l, and BUN: Creatinine ratio is 20:1.

Difference between pre-renal, renal, and post-renal AKI:

  Pre renal  Renal Post renal
Urine osmolality >500 mOsm/kg <350mOsm/kg <400 mOsm/kg
Urine Na <20 meq/l >40meq/l Variable
FeNa <1 >2 Variable
Urine creatinine/plasma creatinine >40:1 <20:1 <20:1
BUN: Creatinine  >20:1 <20:1 >20:1
Urine microscopy  Hyaline Muddy brown cast Normal or RBC/WBC

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is brought to the ER after he was hit by a motorbike as he was crossing the road. He sustained injuries over his abdomen with visible bruising. His blood pressure is 80/50 and IV fluids are immediately instituted. What is the next best step for this patient?
questions.solution:
In this patient with a blunt abdominal injury who is hemodynamically unstable, the next best step is to do FAST-focused abdominal sonography in trauma.

Management of blunt abdominal injury: Primary assessment (ie, the primary survey) follows the ABCDE pattern: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability (neurologic status), and Exposure.

Further management depends on the hemodynamic condition of the patient as shown below.

FAST-focused abdominal sonography in trauma is a rapidly obtainable ultrasound examination that assesses for intraperitoneal fluid. The regions visualised are

  • Right upper quadrant: Assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison's pouch.
  • Left upper quadrant: Assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury.
  • Suprapubic region: Assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas. 

Extended FAST(eFAST) is becoming a common investigation when a thoracic injury is also suspected. An additional region visualised here is

  • Subxiphoid view: Assess for pericardial effusion, cardiac tamponade, free blood and air in the hemithoraces and left lobe liver injuries.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with long-standing complaints of dysphagia which was getting worse for the past 4 months. A barium swallow was performed and it showed the following finding. Which of the following is the definitive treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient likely has achalasia cardia and the definitive treatment is Heller's myotomy. Surgical management is the first-line treatment modality. 

Achalasia or 'failure to relax' in Greek occurs due to the lack of ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus (Auerbach's). The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax leading to dysphagia, regurgitation of food, and progressive dilation of the esophagus proximal to the constriction. 

Barium radiology shows hold-up in the distal esophagus, abnormal contractions in the oesophageal body, and a tapering stricture in the distal esophagus often described as a ‘bird’s beak’.

Laparoscopic Heller's myotomy is the procedure of choice. Here, the muscles of the lower esophagus and cardia are cut. However, this can cause iatrogenic gastroesophageal reflux (GERD) due to damage to the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). Thus, newer techniques involve a partial fundoplication like Dor's procedure to reinforce the sphincter and reduce GERD symptoms. 

Endoscopic myotomy is a newer, alternate procedure. Here, a submucosal tunnel is formed in the mid esophagus region that allows a long myotomy. 

Option A: Calcium channel blockers can be given in the initial stages of the disease. They relieve the chest pressure that occurs around mealtimes. However, they are not permanent treatments and can be used while waiting for surgery.  

Option B: Botulinum toxin injection can be used as a treatment in patients who may not be candidates for surgery or dilatation. Limitations to botulinum toxin injections are that the effect is short-lived (6-12 months) and patients often require multiple treatments.

Option C: Pneumatic dilatation of the LES has is successful in 75% of patients. It involves using a balloon to stretch the LES and improve competence. It requires multiple sessions and has a low risk of esophageal perforation.

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty ward with right lower abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. On examination, there is increased pain in the right lower quadrant when palpating the left lower quadrant. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The given triad of clinical features, namely fever, nausea, and right lower abdominal pain, is the Murphy triad. It is suggestive of acute appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa can cause pain in the right iliac fossa. This sign is called the Rovsing sign.

This pain is due to the backflow of gases from the colon into the inflamed right intestine when the left lower abdomen is palpated.

Other options:

Option B: Aaron sign-Pain or pressure in epigastrium or anterior chest with persistent firm pressure applied to McBurney’s point. It is seen in acute appendicitis.

Option C: Dunphy sign-pain on coughing.It is seen in acute appendicitis.

Option D: McBurney sign-it refers to deep tenderness at McBurney's point. It is seen in acute appendicitis.

Related Pearl: Signs in appendicitis

Sign

questions.text: A mother brought her 16-year-old daughter to the hospital with the complaints of primary amenorrhea. On evaluation axillary and pubic hair were present and other secondary sexual characteristics normal.LH and FSH levels are normal and USG showed absence of uterus.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child does not have any uterus but has normal sex hormones and normal secondary sexual characteristics suggesting it is a case of MRKH( Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser).

A similar presentation is seen in Androgen insensitivity but LH and FSH levels would be abnormal in that case.

 

Presentation Mullarian agenesis  Androgen insensitivity /Testicular feminization syndrome 
Inheritance pattren Sporaidic  X-linked recessive
Karyotype  46, XX 46, XY
Breast development  Yes  Yes
Axillary and pubic hair Yes No
Uterus Absent Absent
Gonad Ovary Testis (Intraabdominal)
Testosterone  Female levels Male levels
Associated anomoly Yes  No

 

Turner's syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality with partial or complete monosomy of the X chromosome (45+XO). In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure that is hypogonadism. The clinical picture of amenorrhea, short stature, webbed neck, low hairline at the back of the neck, widely spaced nipples, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is seen in Turner's syndrome.

Sweyer syndrome or pure gonadal dysgenesis occurs as a result of a mutation in the SRY gene. This leads to underdeveloped, dysgenetic gonads that fail to produce androgens or anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH). The following features are seen: 

  • Normal prepubertal female phenotype- Absent or poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Normal Müllerian system development due to the absence of AMH. (Uterus and cervix present)
  • Female external genitalia
  • Presence of dysgenetic testes that cannot produce AMH or sex hormones. They have a risk of malignant transformation.

As there is gonadal dysgenesis in a patient with 46 XY karyotype, they are actually determined to be males and are a type of male pseudohermaphrodite. They present with primary amenorrhoea, absence of secondary sex characters, and female external genitalia.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Minimal to absent

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

46 XY

46 XX

45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism

46 XY

 

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: Ovarian drilling is done in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Laparoscopic Ovarian drilling is a surgical management procedure done for Polycystic ovarian syndrome(PCOS).  

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. The Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (Oligo/amenorrhoea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasound.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 20 follicles and/or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

The ultrasound image given below shows an enlarged ovary seen in PCOS with multiple follicles in the periphery.

Management of PCOS:

  • Weight reduction and lifestyle changes (like smoking cessation).
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP) are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism.
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin. Acarbose can be used if metformin is contraindicated
  • Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of the ovarian capsule. This is done either by laser or by unipolar electrocautery. The procedure's end goal is to reduce the amount of androgen-producing tissue.

Disadvantages include the risks of pelvic adhesion formation and concerns regarding long-term effects on ovarian reserve.

It can be useful in patients:

  • fail to ovulate with clomiphene citrate,
  • who are at risk for ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, 
  • who desire to minimize their risk for multifetal gestation. 

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A primigravida was admitted in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. In view of the prolonged second stage of labor, a mediolateral episiotomy was given to aid instrumental delivery.  It is usually angled at ______
questions.solution:
The mediolateral episiotomy is angled at 60°.

Episiotomy is a surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labour. It is done to 

  • To enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus.
  • To minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia
  • To reduce the stress and strain on the fetal head.

It is given during crowning when the head is visible. There are many types like median, mediolateral, lateral and j shaped. Among these, mediolateral episiotomy is preferred.

The mediolateral episiotomy begins at the midline of the fourchette and is directed to the right or left at an angle 60 degrees off the midline. This angle accounts for stretch distortion of perineal anatomy during crowning. After delivery and distortion resolution, it ultimately yields an incision 45-degrees from the midline.

 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A 6 month old child weighing  7 kg with history of 8-10 episodes of loose stools is lethargic with loss of skin turgor and sunken anterior fontanelle. He is evaluated to have severe dehydration. How much fluid should be given in the first 1 hour of fluid resuscitation ?
questions.solution:
This child with severe dehydration should be resuscitated with 210 ml of IV fluids in the first one hour.

According to IMNCI guidelines, severe dehydration requires treatment with IV fluids (Plan C). Rehydration with 100ml/kg of IV fluids is done as shown below :

Age 30ml/kg 70ml/kg
<12 mo 1 hr 5 hr
>12 mo 30 min 2.5 hr

As this child is < 12 months of age, in the first one hour, fluid requirement = 30ml/kg i.e. 30*7 = 210 ml.

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with end-stage renal disease presents with back pain. He gives a history of frequent pathological fractures. Identify the characteristic finding seen in his lumbosacral radiograph given below.
questions.solution:
The radiograph given above shows a Rugger jersey spine which is a characteristic feature of renal osteodystrophy. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of renal osteodystrophy which is caused by hyperparathyroidism secondary to chronic renal disease. 

Rugger jersey appearance is seen due to osteosclerosis of the superior and inferior vertebral endplates. This occurs due to excess osteoid formation by the osteoblasts to counteract increased bone resorption. The term 'rugger jersey’ appearance is used because there are alternating bands of increased and decreased bone density, similar to the jersey of a rugby player.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female complains of headache, backache, decreased sexual desire, vomiting, and diarrhoea. This is associated with weakness and paralysis. On further probing, no organic cause is found. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of one or more somatic symptoms in the absence of an organic cause for more than 6 months is suggestive of somatic symptom disorder.

DSM-5 criteria for the diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder: 

  • One or more somatic symptoms that are distressing or result in significant disruption of daily life.
  • Excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to the somatic symptoms or associ­ated health concerns as manifested by at least one of the following:
    • Disproportionate and persistent thoughts about the seriousness of one’s symptoms.
    • Persistently high level of anxiety about health or symptoms.
    • Excessive time and energy devoted to these symptoms or health concerns.
  • Although any one somatic symptom may not be continuously present, the state of be­ing symptomatic is persistent (typically more than 6 months).

 Treatment: Psychotherapy

Related Pearl: Somatoform Disorder

Somatoform Disorder

Key features of somatic symptom and related disorders

Somatic symptom disorder

Excessive anxiety and preoccupation with ≥1 unexplained symptom

Illness anxiety disorder

(hypochondriasis)

Fear of having a serious illness despite few or no symptoms and consistently negative evaluations

Conversion disorder

(functional neurologic symptom disorder)

Neurologic symptom  incompatible with any known neurologic disease, often acute onset associated with stress

Factitious disorder

Intentional falsification or inducement of symptoms with a goal to assume the sick role

Malingering

Falsification or exaggeration of symptoms to obtain external incentives (secondary gain)

questions.text: A child with tetralogy of fallot is planned for corrective surgery. Which is the ideal induction agent of choice?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is the induction agent of choice in patients with Tetralogy of Fallot because it maintains or increases systemic vascular resistance and increases cardiac output. Thus it does not aggravate the right to left shunt seen in such cases.

Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by subpulmonic stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, ventricular septal defect and overriding of the aorta. This results in a right to left shunt through the ventricular septal defect and consequent cyanosis. Ketamine does not increase pulmonary vascular resistance and is safe to administer in children.

Ketamine is the agent of choice in all congenital heart diseases with cyanosis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with lesions on her face as shown in the image. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The Image shows typical erythematous papules and nodules along with few whiteheads. The face appears to be very oily as well which suggests acne vulgaris. This comes under grade III acne.

Related Pearl: Key Chart to help differentiate lesions on face

Key Chart to help Differentiate Lesions on face

questions.text: Obliteration of right cardiac border on chest X-Ray indicates pathology involving which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Right middle lobe pathology causes obliteration of right cardiac border.

The silhouette sign is the loss of clear demarcation between normal lung and soft tissue (e.g., heart, diaphragm). This occurs when the lung parenchyma is no longer filled with air and the contrast between air and soft tissue is lost.

The left image is a normal chest radiograph with the red line indicating the silhouette of the right heart border and right middle lobe.

The right image shows the same red line delineating where the silhouette should be, but is lost due to consolidation in the right middle lobe.

questions.text: The Bone scan in multiple myeloma shows _____
questions.solution:
The Bone scan in multiple myeloma shows cold spot, as there is no compensatory osteoblastic activity.

Multiple myelomas are the most common primary malignant bone neoplasm in adults arising from red marrow due to the monoclonal proliferation of the plasma cells.

Related Pearl: Bone scan findings

Causes of a hot spot

Causes of a cold spot

Osteomyelitis

Bone tumors and metastases

Fibrous dysplasia

Trauma (fracture healing)

Avascular necrosis

Perthes disease

Paget’s disease

Hyperparathyroidism

Multiple myeloma

Fibrous cortical defect

Pseudoarthrosis

questions.text: The most common complication following splenectomy is _______.

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of greater curvature of stomach

questions.solution:
Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common complication after splenectomy.

Other complications of splenectomy include:

  • OPSI (Overwhelming post-splenectomy infection)is the most common fatal late complication of splenectomy.
  • Avascular necrosis of the greater curvature of the stomach is a rare complication that can occur after ligation of short gastric vessels.
  • Damage to the tail of the pancreas during surgery can lead to pancreatitis, a localized abscess, or pancreatic fistula.
  • Hemorrhage during the perioperative period etc.
